title: How to Make a Scarecrow Hat

methods.name: Covering a Foam Hat with Burlap

steps.headline: Select a foam hat.
steps.description: Visit a craft store, toy store, or another establishment that sells costuming supplies. Purchase a foam hat. Pick a style that seems appropriate for your scarecrow in terms of shape, but don’t worry about other features like color, since it will be covered with burlap in the end.

steps.headline: Trace an outline on your burlap.
steps.description: Unroll a large swath of burlap and center your hat on top of it, right way up. Trace a circle (or whichever shape matches that of your particular hat) around the hat. Make it large enough for the circle to cover all of the hat’s exterior, with at least a few extra inches between the brim and your circle.

steps.headline: Cut out the outline.
steps.description: Use fabric scissors to cut the circle free from the roll of burlap. If you're worried about making your circle too small, err on the side of caution and go for one that's too big. The excess can be repurposed later on if you need to trim it off.

steps.headline: Glue the burlap to your hat.
steps.description:
First, drape your burlap circle over your hat and center it. Make sure it’s long enough to hang over the brim by a few inches on all sides. Then lift the burlap’s loose end and apply glue to a swath of the hat’s brim. Press the burlap down into the glue to stick the two together. Then:
Use pins if needed to secure glued areas in place so the burlap doesn’t move around as you work. Continue applying beads of glue along the brim and pressing the burlap into it until you have completed the whole brim. Secure the burlap with pins if desired to keep it in place while the glue dries.

steps.headline: Make a band for your hat.
steps.description: Cut out a new length of burlap. Make it long enough to wrap around the hat's crown and then overlap itself by an inch or so. Glue the back of one end to the burlap circle, wrap the length around the crown, and glue the back of the free end to where it overlaps the first end.

steps.headline: Add some patches.
steps.description: Cut out some small squares of burlap from your roll. Or, if you needed to trim any excess material from your circle, cut some squares from that. Glue these “patches” where desired to accentuate the scarecrow’s patched-together look.

steps.headline: Cut out a circle of felt for your hat.
steps.description: How large of a circle you need depends on the size of the head in question, so use a cloth measuring tape to determine how far down from the crown you want the brim of hat to hang. Double that figure and use a ruler to trace two perpendicular lines of equal length in an X-shape on your unrolled fabric. Then trace a circle connecting the ends of each line and cut out the outline of your circle. Don’t worry if your circle is less than perfect. Scarecrows aren’t known for flawlessly tailored clothes.

steps.headline: Shape your hat.
steps.description: Drape the felt circle over the head in question. Create pleats running from crown to brim along the back and sides of your hat by pinching the material into a crease for each pleat and then folding it over slightly. Secure each pleat in place with strips of masking tape where your brim begins. If the hat is for yourself, you may need to ask a partner to help with this step to make life easier. Alternately, you could try using an inflated ball that’s roughly the same size and shape of your head.

steps.headline: Glue the pleats into place.
steps.description: Remove the felt from the person’s head. Apply beads of hot glue with a glue gun under the fold of each pleat. Leave your strips of tape in place to hold the pleats together until the glue dries.

steps.headline: Make a hat band.
steps.description: Place the hat back on the person’s head once the hot glue has dried. Cut a length of fabric (either the same felt as before, or any other that you want to use as an accent) that’s long enough to wrap their head where you want the brim to begin. Tape the band in place, then remove the hat. As before, a partner may make this step easier if the hat is for you.

steps.headline: Add “straw.” Stick real straw in between your band and your hat, or make your own if needed.
steps.description: Cut thin strips of cardstock paper. Then fold each one accordian-style to create a crinkled look. Line the band with them as desired. Regular printer paper might hold up for a while if you’re only wearing the hat once, but otherwise go with cardstock. Since it’s thicker than regular paper, it will stand up longer.

steps.headline: Glue the band, straw, and flowers to your hat.
steps.description: Use your hot glue gun to add beads of glue between the headband and hat. Make sure to cover any straw behind the band, too. Then, if desired, glue the back(s) of one or two flowerheads to the front of the band to add a touch of farm-and-garden to your hat.

steps.headline: Prepare your bag.
steps.description: Cut a large brown paper bag open along one corner. Spread it flat on your worktable. Try to smooth out any creases as best you can.

steps.headline: Shape your hat.
steps.description:
If you’re making the hat for someone else, drape the bag over their head and center it. Smooth the paper over their skull where the hat will cover it. Make new creases and fold them over to create pleats where needed. Then wrap wide tape around the bag to act as a hat band and hold its shape. If you’re making it for yourself:
Do the same over an inflatable ball that’s roughly the same size and shape as your head. If using a ball, you may need a partner to hold it still while you tape.

steps.headline: Trim away excess paper if desired.
steps.description: Give the brim of your hat a look over. If there’s more paper than you’d like between its edges and the tape-band, cut away the excess with scissors. Then remove the hat from your model.

steps.headline: Decorate.
steps.description: Cut a length of fabric to tie or glue around the tape for a more eye-catching hat band. Stuff that with straw or crinkled cardstock paper. Cut small squares from your excess paper or another paper bag, glue these to the hat where you please, and use markers to draw stitches around their edges to transform them into patches.

tyn: Fabric, straw, and markers for decorating
text:
Covering a Foam Hat with Burlap Select a foam hat. Visit a craft store, toy store, or another establishment that sells costuming supplies. Purchase a foam hat. Pick a style that seems appropriate for your scarecrow in terms of shape, but don’t worry about other features like color, since it will be covered with burlap in the end. Trace an outline on your burlap. Unroll a large swath of burlap and center your hat on top of it, right way up. Trace a circle (or whichever shape matches that of your particular hat) around the hat. Make it large enough for the circle to cover all of the hat’s exterior, with at least a few extra inches between the brim and your circle. Cut out the outline. Use fabric scissors to cut the circle free from the roll of burlap. If you're worried about making your circle too small, err on the side of caution and go for one that's too big. The excess can be repurposed later on if you need to trim it off. Glue the burlap to your hat. First, drape your burlap circle over your hat and center it. Make sure it’s long enough to hang over the brim by a few inches on all sides. Then lift the burlap’s loose end and apply glue to a swath of the hat’s brim. Press the burlap down into the glue to stick the two together. Then:
Use pins if needed to secure glued areas in place so the burlap doesn’t move around as you work. Continue applying beads of glue along the brim and pressing the burlap into it until you have completed the whole brim. Secure the burlap with pins if desired to keep it in place while the glue dries. Make a band for your hat. Cut out a new length of burlap. Make it long enough to wrap around the hat's crown and then overlap itself by an inch or so. Glue the back of one end to the burlap circle, wrap the length around the crown, and glue the back of the free end to where it overlaps the first end. Add some patches. Cut out some small squares of burlap from your roll. Or, if you needed to trim any excess material from your circle, cut some squares from that. Glue these “patches” where desired to accentuate the scarecrow’s patched-together look. Creating a Felt Hat Cut out a circle of felt for your hat. How large of a circle you need depends on the size of the head in question, so use a cloth measuring tape to determine how far down from the crown you want the brim of hat to hang. Double that figure and use a ruler to trace two perpendicular lines of equal length in an X-shape on your unrolled fabric. Then trace a circle connecting the ends of each line and cut out the outline of your circle. Don’t worry if your circle is less than perfect. Scarecrows aren’t known for flawlessly tailored clothes. Shape your hat. Drape the felt circle over the head in question. Create pleats running from crown to brim along the back and sides of your hat by pinching the material into a crease for each pleat and then folding it over slightly. Secure each pleat in place with strips of masking tape where your brim begins. If the hat is for yourself, you may need to ask a partner to help with this step to make life easier. Alternately, you could try using an inflated ball that’s roughly the same size and shape of your head. Glue the pleats into place. Remove the felt from the person’s head. Apply beads of hot glue with a glue gun under the fold of each pleat. Leave your strips of tape in place to hold the pleats together until the glue dries. Make a hat band. Place the hat back on the person’s head once the hot glue has dried. Cut a length of fabric (either the same felt as before, or any other that you want to use as an accent) that’s long enough to wrap their head where you want the brim to begin. Tape the band in place, then remove the hat. As before, a partner may make this step easier if the hat is for you. Add “straw.” Stick real straw in between your band and your hat, or make your own if needed. Cut thin strips of cardstock paper. Then fold each one accordian-style to create a crinkled look. Line the band with them as desired. Regular printer paper might hold up for a while if you’re only wearing the hat once, but otherwise go with cardstock. Since it’s thicker than regular paper, it will stand up longer. Glue the band, straw, and flowers to your hat. Use your hot glue gun to add beads of glue between the headband and hat. Make sure to cover any straw behind the band, too. Then, if desired, glue the back(s) of one or two flowerheads to the front of the band to add a touch of farm-and-garden to your hat. Using a Brown Paper Bag Prepare your bag. Cut a large brown paper bag open along one corner. Spread it flat on your worktable. Try to smooth out any creases as best you can. Shape your hat. If you’re making the hat for someone else, drape the bag over their head and center it. Smooth the paper over their skull where the hat will cover it. Make new creases and fold them over to create pleats where needed. Then wrap wide tape around the bag to act as a hat band and hold its shape. If you’re making it for yourself:
Do the same over an inflatable ball that’s roughly the same size and shape as your head. If using a ball, you may need a partner to hold it still while you tape. Trim away excess paper if desired. Give the brim of your hat a look over. If there’s more paper than you’d like between its edges and the tape-band, cut away the excess with scissors. Then remove the hat from your model. Decorate. Cut a length of fabric to tie or glue around the tape for a more eye-catching hat band. Stuff that with straw or crinkled cardstock paper. Cut small squares from your excess paper or another paper bag, glue these to the hat where you please, and use markers to draw stitches around their edges to transform them into patches.
sentences: Covering a Foam Hat with Burlap Select a foam hat.
Visit a craft store, toy store, or another establishment that sells costuming supplies.
Purchase a foam hat.
Pick a style that seems appropriate for your scarecrow in terms of shape, but don’t worry about other features like color, since it will be covered with burlap in the end.
Trace an outline on your burlap.
Unroll a large swath of burlap and center your hat on top of it, right way up.
Trace a circle (or whichever shape matches that of your particular hat) around the hat.
Make it large enough for the circle to cover all of the hat’s exterior, with at least a few extra inches between the brim and your circle.
Cut out the outline.
Use fabric scissors to cut the circle free from the roll of burlap.
If you're worried about making your circle too small, err on the side of caution and go for one that's too big.
The excess can be repurposed later on if you need to trim it off.
Glue the burlap to your hat.
First, drape your burlap circle over your hat and center it.
Make sure it’s long enough to hang over the brim by a few inches on all sides.
Then lift the burlap’s loose end and apply glue to a swath of the hat’s brim.
Press the burlap down into the glue to stick the two together.

Then:
Use pins if needed to secure glued areas in place so the burlap doesn’t move around as you work.
Continue applying beads of glue along the brim and pressing the burlap into it until you have completed the whole brim.
Secure the burlap with pins if desired to keep it in place while the glue dries.
Make a band for your hat.
Cut out a new length of burlap.
Make it long enough to wrap around the hat's crown and then overlap itself by an inch or so.
Glue the back of one end to the burlap circle, wrap the length around the crown, and glue the back of the free end to where it overlaps the first end.
Add some patches.
Cut out some small squares of burlap from your roll.
Or, if you needed to trim any excess material from your circle, cut some squares from that.
Glue these “patches” where desired to accentuate the scarecrow’s patched-together look.
Creating a Felt Hat Cut out a circle of felt for your hat.
How large of a circle you need depends on the size of the head in question, so use a cloth measuring tape to determine how far down from the crown you want the brim of hat to hang.
Double that figure and use a ruler to trace two perpendicular lines of equal length in an X-shape on your unrolled fabric.
Then trace a circle connecting the ends of each line and cut out the outline of your circle.
Don’t worry if your circle is less than perfect.
Scarecrows aren’t known for flawlessly tailored clothes.
Shape your hat.
Drape the felt circle over the head in question.
Create pleats running from crown to brim along the back and sides of your hat by pinching the material into a crease for each pleat and then folding it over slightly.
Secure each pleat in place with strips of masking tape where your brim begins.
If the hat is for yourself, you may need to ask a partner to help with this step to make life easier.
Alternately, you could try using an inflated ball that’s roughly the same size and shape of your head.
Glue the pleats into place.
Remove the felt from the person’s head.
Apply beads of hot glue with a glue gun under the fold of each pleat.
Leave your strips of tape in place to hold the pleats together until the glue dries.
Make a hat band.
Place the hat back on the person’s head once the hot glue has dried.
Cut a length of fabric (either the same felt as before, or any other that you want to use as an accent) that’s long enough to wrap their head where you want the brim to begin.
Tape the band in place, then remove the hat.
As before, a partner may make this step easier if the hat is for you.
Add “straw.” Stick real straw in between your band and your hat, or make your own if needed.
Cut thin strips of cardstock paper.
Then fold each one accordian-style to create a crinkled look.
Line the band with them as desired.
Regular printer paper might hold up for a while if you’re only wearing the hat once, but otherwise go with cardstock.
Since it’s thicker than regular paper, it will stand up longer.
Glue the band, straw, and flowers to your hat.
Use your hot glue gun to add beads of glue between the headband and hat.
Make sure to cover any straw behind the band, too.
Then, if desired, glue the back(s) of one or two flowerheads to the front of the band to add a touch of farm-and-garden to your hat.
Using a Brown Paper Bag Prepare your bag.
Cut a large brown paper bag open along one corner.
Spread it flat on your worktable.
Try to smooth out any creases as best you can.
Shape your hat.
If you’re making the hat for someone else, drape the bag over their head and center it.
Smooth the paper over their skull where the hat will cover it.
Make new creases and fold them over to create pleats where needed.
Then wrap wide tape around the bag to act as a hat band and hold its shape.

If you’re making it for yourself:
Do the same over an inflatable ball that’s roughly the same size and shape as your head.
If using a ball, you may need a partner to hold it still while you tape.
Trim away excess paper if desired.
Give the brim of your hat a look over.
If there’s more paper than you’d like between its edges and the tape-band, cut away the excess with scissors.
Then remove the hat from your model.
Decorate.
Cut a length of fabric to tie or glue around the tape for a more eye-catching hat band.
Stuff that with straw or crinkled cardstock paper.
Cut small squares from your excess paper or another paper bag, glue these to the hat where you please, and use markers to draw stitches around their edges to transform them into patches.
